name: Incidence Axiom I-1
statement: For every two distinct points, there exists a unique line that contains them.
philosophy: Defines the fundamental relational nature of geometry: space is structured by connections between points.

name: Incidence Axiom I-2
statement: Every line contains at least two distinct points.
philosophy: A line is defined not in isolation but by the distinct points that it contains.

name: Incidence Axiom I-3
statement: There exist at least three non-collinear points.
philosophy: Guarantees the existence of two-dimensional structure in geometry by ensuring not all points lie on a single line.

name: Betweenness Axiom II-1
statement: If B is between A and C, then A, B, and C are three distinct points on the same line, and B is also between C and A.
formal: ∀a ∀b ∀c (Between(a, b, c) → (Collinear(a, b, c) ∧ Between(c, b, a)))
philosophy: Introduces symmetry in the concept of betweenness and reinforces linear ordering.

name: Congruence Axiom III-1
statement: Congruence of segments is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.
formal: ∀a ∀b Congruent(a, b, a, b) ∧ Symmetry(Congruent) ∧ Transitivity(Congruent)
philosophy: Defines congruence as an equivalence relation, foundational for geometric transformations.
